Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Sensible Privacy: Pragmatic Privacy Controls in an Era of Sensor-Enabled Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social networking and sensor-rich devices such as smartphones are becoming increasingly pervasive in today's society. People can share information concerning their location, activity, fitness, and health with their friends and family while benefiting from applications that leverage such information. Yet, users already find managing their privacy to be challenging, and the complexity involved in doing so is bound to increase. Usable techniques are required to enable people to effectively manage the dissemination of their private information as sensed by their mobile devices and sensors in their environment.

This project explores `sensible' privacy controls and feedback mechanisms that allow people (or automated mechanisms acting on their behalf) to respond to unanticipated patterns and actual uses of their information in a way that is usable and intuitive. This approach has two advantages: 1) people need only care about the subset of data and usage scenarios that have the potential to violate their privacy, thus reducing the amount of data to which they must regulate access; and 2) people make better decisions concerning such access when these decisions are made in a context where they know how their data is being used.

Sensible privacy mechanisms can have a profound and positive societal impact by not only helping people control their privacy, but also potentially increasing their participation in sensor-enabled computing because of this added control. This project firmly integrates education into the research through research experiences for underrepresented groups and the development of course modules on privacy at the undergraduate and graduate levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project yielded significant insights into managing privacy in the context of modern sensor-enabled computing. In the context of pervasive digital photography and sharing on social media, this project studied the privacy concerns of young adults and their workarounds when technology fell short. These workarounds yielded design insights for managing privacy throughout the 'lifecycle of a photo.' Our subsequent work also studied various 'sanctioning' strategies people use online to suggest how people might suitably negotiate their privacy concerns with and without technology. With the advent of wearable cameras such as augmented reality glasses and 'lifelogging' cameras, our work studied the privacy concerns and behaviors of lifeloggers. As a result, we also developed techniques to detect sensitive content within lifelogging photos, thereby addressing privacy issues for the next generation of digital photography.


Our work also analyzed how people's visibility -- as a cost for more privacy -- is affected by the use of various pseudonyms on social media. We found a 'glass ceiling' effect on Twitter, where female-sounding aliases achieved less visibility compared to male-sounding aliases.  Our work showed that social media can perpetuate old inequalities online, and there are social costs that remain even when people attempt anonymous interactions. 


This project also studied privacy issues for vulnerable populations. Our work explored the physical privacy concerns of people with visual impairments and how a wearable camera-based system might help them assess their surroundings. People with visual impairments also use online services to have questions answered about photos they take for assistive purposes. However, various unintended background objects are captured and shared with crowdworkers leading to potential privacy harms. This work yielded insights into 'humanizing' system designs to better account for the needs of vulnerable populations. Our work also studied the privacy concerns of college ROTC (Reserve Officers' Training Corps) students transitioning into military culture and how they cope with personal crises. This work yielded insights into the design of systems for managing the privacy of such populations, which are highly selective in what they disclose to different groups of people.


In the context of apps on mobile platforms accessing sensitive data about the owners, we studied a crowdsourcing approach to narrow down privacy settings that improve privacy without sacrificing the usability of the app. For online social media, our work also examined the privacy concerns of people affected by various 'transparency' features. Some social platforms provide information about who has viewed one's profile, or in the case of instant messaging, whether a recipient has seen one's message. Our work yielded design insights for social systems, which also need to account for the privacy of the viewers of information. Our work also studied the timing of providing privacy feedback to people about when viewers are accessing their data. In particular, we found that the sense of privacy violation was heightened when feedback about location accesses was immediate. A moderate delay may serve as a compromise to minimize interruption and avoid overly alarming reactions to immediate privacy feedback.


This project also sought to involve undergraduate students in research as well as recruit undergraduate students from underrepresented groups. Fourteen undergraduate students worked on this project, of which five were African American or students from HBCU institutions, and three were women.
